title: Why do some call Bernie Sanders a socialist? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s due to a combination of ignorance, political marketing, and Bernie’s historical political alignment. Many political and economic illiterate Americans have been misguided into thinking anything from welfare to taxes are “socialist”, and that European countries are “socialist” when they’re really capitalist economies, some of which like the Nordic countries are best described as “social democracies”. The ideology Bernie Sanders espoused during his political campaign was close to “social democracy”, or what Noam Chomsky described as “New Deal liberalism”. One can only speculate why Bernie Sanders called himself and his political positions “democratic socialism” during his campaign, but it isn’t to difficult to understand why he did: if he hadn’t, he would have been derided as a “socialist” by conservatives in the media, by calling himself a “democratic socialist” he preempted this outcome and stood out from the other candidates. In the past, Bernie Sanders actually did espouse socialist views by calling for public ownership and democratic management of the economy. Whether or not he’s still an actual democratic socialist or not we can’t know for certain; either way, much of his policy platform and his ideology is now pro-capitalism and liberal.

He is labeled as a socialist because he has given himself that label. He adds “Democratic” in front to distinguish his brand from the authoritarian versions. It is an odd thing to do since he is really more of a Social Democrat, which is a form of capitalism but it just has higher income taxes. It makes little difference however since if you take enough of someone’s income you might as well take the means of production as well since the effect is the same. Given our current President I would vote for Sanders even though I don’t agree with much of his approach. He would still have Congress to deal with and much of what he talks about wouldn’t make it though Congress. He is less corrupt, more competent than Trump so I’d willingly make the trade. I’d support Singer Payer healthcare but that’s about it. Eventually (hopefully) people will realize that there isn’t enough wealth to redistribute, given the large population, to make much of a difference on a per capita basis and the only result would be to make everyone poorer and to remove the part of the economy producing the growth since no one is going to continue to outproduce everyone else if you take that wealth. You can’t eat the rich, it makes no sense to kill the goose that laid the golden egg. People just need to get a grip on envy and jealousy. If people could work together there could be a little more of a safety net for those at the bottom of the economic ladder. That’s all that is needed.
